DIV1.P: THE FARCE OF THE VILLAGE LAWYER.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, SMOKE-ALLEY.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: NAY, nay good wife not so loud, or I vanish. Five and twenty years have I expos'd my organs of hearing (aye, and though I say it, without whining too) to the encounter of the toughest lungs in Westminster Hall, with no worse effect as yet, than a moderate deafness of the left ear; and a whizzing from time to time in the right, but that dear lovely, indefatigable tongue of thine, so far outdins he bar itself, that though a lawyer—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: A lawyer! why in that trim you look more like a client, than a lawyer, and no one, to see you in such a dress, wou'd imagine you had ever carried on a suit, in any one's name but your own. Out upon you, you are a disgrace to the profession, and had you a grain of spirit—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P:
Spirit! oh, there at least you wrong me, and I defy any practitioner of twice my standing to produce more instances of spirit, than I have; who exposes him∣self to the displeasure of the judges; or the censure of
the courts. Shew me the man that sets the pedantic regulations of common practice more at defiance than I have done▪ hav'n't I been obliged to quit the London courts only for displaying too much spirit on a certain occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: Very fine truly! and do you boast of your blunders, and make a merit of your disgrace?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: This accident to be sure forces me to try my talents in the obscurity of rural practice; and yet since our removal to this village, though next door to Jus∣tice Mittimus, the best accustom'd Magistrate in the whole country, no favourable opportunity has offer'd; not a hare has been snar'd, or a head broke, or (what is stranger still) a single bastard born, though we have been here a whole fortnight, nay the very cattle keep out of pound, to spite me. But come have a little pa∣tience, times will mend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: And in the mean time, your wife is to starve, and your daughter, to lose the opportunity of settling herself in the world, by a match with one or other of the young men, who court her, and whom the pover∣ty of your appearance frighten away.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P:
Why to say the truth there is nothing in my dress that can bring either lovers to my daughter, or clients to myself. Mankind is govern'd by shew, and the surest way to obtain the countenance of the world is never to appear to want it. Cou'd I but once put on the appearance of business, the reality perhaps wou'd soon follow, let me see—cou'dn't I—yes I have it—I'll
go, and purchase me a handsome suit of clothes im∣mediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: A handsome suit of clothes! what, without a farthing in your pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why not?—in London all your handsome suits are purchas'd the same way.—What colour shall I chuse? bats▪wing—or—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: Oh no matter for the colour if you can find any one kind enough to trust you with the cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Then to lose no time, I'll step over the way to the rich drapers, my neighbour Snarl's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: To neighbour Snarl's! have a care what you do there. You know his Son Charles is in love with our Harriet, and wou'd have married her before now, but for fear of his father; I wou'd not for the world you should do any thing to overthrow my daughter's hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Never fear, step in and fetch my hat and gown. Exit▪ Mrs S.
I have just time to slip it on; it will give me a more creditable appearance before old Snarl, and these rags of mine into the bargain.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter MRS SCOUT, with gown and hat.
DIV2.P: Aye, this will do.—How many sleek, spruce, demure looking gowns are there in the world, as well as this, good for nothing else, but covering things not fit to be seen. [Exeunt.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE.—SNARL'S shop, Day-book, pen and ink, cloath on counter, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Well Son, I order'd you to enquire me out a Shepherd instead of that dog Sheepface; didn't I?

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: Why surely Father, you have no fault to find with Sheepface.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No; only that he is a thief! an arrant thief!

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: I always found Sheepface a very faithful ser∣vant.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: To you he may, but not to me; he has been but a month in my service, and there are fourteen of my wethers missing, now it is impossible so great a number in so short a time cou'd die of the rot, as he says.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: You don't consider what a havock a disorder sometimes makes.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: With the help of a Doctor, I grant you, but my sheep ha! no Doctor, poor things! yet they cou'd not have made more haste if they had been prescrib'd for, by the whole faculty.—As for that dog, Sheepface, I have suspected him for sometime: but last night I caught him in the fact, and this morning I mean to bring him before Justice Mittimus; but first of all, I must know exactly, what's my loss. Reach me the ac∣count of the flock. (sits down) And if neighbour Gripe, the constable enquires for me; send him this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P: (aside to Sheepface.) Sheepface all's out I find, ather's confoundedly angry, try what you can do to soften it, but beware of speaking. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Let me see;—"bought of Farmer Clod."—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Save your good worship, Sweet Master Snarl.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: How villain, have you the impudence to ap∣pear in my sight, after the tricks you have play'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Only to tell your sweet worship, that neigh∣bour Gripe has been talking to me about sheep-steal∣ing, and Justice Mittimus, and your worship, and a power of things, and so I said I wou'dn't make a se∣cret of it to my good master's worship any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Your affected innocence, sha'n't save you, you rascal; didn't I catch you last night killing one of the fattest of my wethers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Only to keep it from dying.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Kill it, to keep it from dying!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Of the rot, an' please your worship. Its a secret I learnt from the doctor in our town. He cur'd most of his patients the same way.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: The doctor, rascal! the doctor has a license to kill from the college.—Such sheep as mine too—there was not in all England, such another breed for Spanish wool.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Be satisfied your worship with the blows you gave me, and let's make up matters, if its your wor∣ship's sweet will and pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: My will and pleasure is to hang you, rascal, to hang you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Consider your worship, I was married but yesterday, leave me to myself a week or two, and who knows but I may save you the trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No, rascal, the gallows is the quickest reme∣dy of the two, and every bit as sure as t'other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Heaven give you good luck of it then, if it must be so, sweet Master Snarl, I must go look for a lawyer, I see, or might will overcome right. Oh dear, that an honest man should be treated so, only for kil∣ling a few sheep to save 'em from dying. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: (sitting down) A dog! but he shall pay for this.—Let me see—two, and two are four—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: The coast is clear at last—now or never.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: And seven—no, nine—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: (aside) Yonder's a piece of cloth now wou'd suit me to a hair. Give me leave Sir, to—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Who's there? Gripe I suppose. Wait a mo∣ment honest Gripe.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I am lawyer Scout your neighbour—I am come to—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I am lawyer Scout, my neighbour's very humble servant; but he and I have no business toge∣ther, that I know of,—"Carried over"—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P:
You'll have another story to tell to-morrow, or I'm much mistaken (aside)—I find Sir, upon look∣ing
over my late father's papers, an account of a debt left unpaid, and I am come—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Its no business of mine; I owe no man a far∣thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I wish I cou'd say as much for myself; but I find that my father was indebted to yours in a small balance of 50 pounds, and as a man of honor I am come home to pay it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: (rising) My dear Sir, ten thousand pardons, for my forgetfulness. I recollect you perfectly now. Yes, you liv'd in the next village, and you and I were sworn comrades formerly. Pray Sir, be seated. (hands a chair.)

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Dear Sir, if those who are indebted to me, had a little of my punctuality, I should be a richer man than I am, but to have my name in any one's book is a thing I can't bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: And yet the generality of people bear it very patiently.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I am upon thorns in a manner, while I owe one a farthing, and for that reason I am come to know when you'll be at leisure to receive the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No time like the prsent.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: True, I have it at home, ready told; but as I have the management of my father's effects, only as guardian for my daughter Harriet, its proper that the other guardians shou'd be by at the payment.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Very true Sir, then what do you think of to∣morrow at three o'clock?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: With all my heart, but I have interrupted you perhaps. (rises) Why Sir, you do more business than all the shopkeepers in this part of the country put together.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I can't complain.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: No, you have such a way with you, that those who buy once, can't for the blood of them, help co∣ming to you again. A pretty bit of cloth this—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Very pretty.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: One meets in your shop, such a generosity of treatment, a politeness of behaviour, that makes it pleasanter to pay money to you than to receive it else∣where. The wool seems tolerably fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Right Spanish wool every hair of it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: So I thought; now we talk of Spanish wool, if I am not mistaken, Mr Snarl, you and I went to school together formerly.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: What, to old Ironfist?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: The same; you were a very handsome youth I remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: So my mother always said.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Egad, for old acquaintance sake, you and I must eat a bit of dinner together to-day. I have a fine goose at home, that a client sent me from Norfolk.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: A goose! that's my favourite dish.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P:
And my wife shall dress it by a family receipt. Its a treasure, that receipt's a perfect treasure. Her uncle, the late Alderman Dumpling, pass'd through
the whole circle of corporation honours, and died Mayor by virtue of that receipt.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Aye! Aye!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Then Mrs Scout will be happy to see you; now I think on't, I promis'd her, that you should have my custom for the future, and to make a beginning I don't care if I have the pattern of a suit of cloaths from you now.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Very happy to accommodate you Sir; what colour wou'd you choose?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Colour! why here's a pretty one enough to my mind Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Very pretty indeed Sir; its an iron grey. Shall I cut off the quantity you want, to have it ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: To have it ready; no Mr. Snarl, pay as you go, that's my rule; pay as you go.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Ecod, an excellent rule it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Do you remember Mr Snarl, the evening we were together at the goose and gridiron?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: What the evening I so roasted our curate.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: The same; you were very severe on him. You had a world of wit.—Pray what must I pay you a yard for this cloth?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Why Sir, another shou'd pay me nineteen and sixpence; but come, you shall have it at nineteen shillings.—Now I think of it. Here's your quantity ready cut.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Ready cut—that's lucky indeed. (snatches up the cloth.)

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Stop a moment, till I measure it before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: O fie! do you think I have any doubt of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: But the price.—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Poo, I never haggle with a friend; I leave all that to you. Good day.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Let my shopman carry it over, and bring back—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: No, no, don't take him from business. It is but a step you know, and I'd carry it twice as far to oblige you. Compliments to Mrs Snarl;—good-bye to you, good-bye. [Exit, Snarl follows.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Lookye, if you want a Lawyer to bring you out of a scrape, my Master's the man for your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: I know it, he stood my friend once when bro∣ther and I were put to trouble;—wou'd you believe it only for mending the complexion of a bald fac'd horse—but I have such a treacherous memory, I don't know how it came about, but some how or other I forgot to pay him.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: He'll not think of that perhaps: at any rate take care not to tell him, who the plaintiff is; for I know he wou'd not on any account be concern'd against Mr Snarl.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: I'll only tell him of my master, without men∣tioning any name; and he'll think I mean the Farmer I liv'd with, when I courted you first.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Do so, here he comes. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Sure I shou'd know that face, I think—Yes, the same, Harkye didn't I save you and your brother from being hang'd some time since at York.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, your worship, yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: By the same token, one of you forgot to pay me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, that was brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: The other was sick at the trial, and died some∣time after in prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: That was not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: So I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: For all that I was sicker, nor brother! and so as I was saying, I am come to beg of your worship to speak for me before the Justice against his worship my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: What the great farmer in the neghbourhood?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: He lives in the neighbourhood sure enough, and your worship shall be paid to your heart's content.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Let me hear your case, and be sure you tell it without disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: You must know then, an' please your wor∣ship, my master gives me but little wages, very small wages, indeed, and so to take amends for that, with∣out doing him any damage, I thought as how I'd best do a little business on my account with a worthy neigh∣bour, a butcher by trade.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: And what kind of business do you carry on?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Under favour. I hinder sheep from dying of the rot.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: There's no harm in that; how do you con∣trive—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Please your worship, I cut their throats, be∣fore they have time to catch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: A very effectual remedy truly, and your mas∣ter perhaps is unreasonable enough to say you do so only to sell the carcases, and keep the money to your∣self?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, your worship, and I can't bear it out of his head, because last night he saw me—I mean—I—must I tell the truth?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Yes, tell the truth here, or how shall we be able to lie to any purpose elsewhere.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: The truth of the matter then is, that last night, after I was married, having a little leisure time upon my hands, I took a walk as far as our pens, and there as I was musing on I don't know what;—out I takes my knife, and so happening by mere accident to put it (craving your worship's pardon) under the throat of a fat wether, I don't know how it came about, but it was not long there, before the wether died all of a sud∣den as a body may say.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: And there was some body looking on, the whole time, eh!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P:
Yes, master from behind the hedge, and so he will have it that 14 wethers, which I sav'd from catch∣ing the rot, died all along of me. And so as your wor∣ship
may see, he laid such a shower of blows upon me as put the bride out of temper the whole night; but I hope your worship will stand my friend, and not let me lose the fruits of my honest industry all at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I understand you; there are two ways of pro∣ceeding in this affair; the first won't put you to a far∣thing of expence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Lets try that by all means.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: With all my heart;—you have scrap'd up something handsome in the course of your practice on your master's sheep.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Heaven knows I have been up late and early for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Your savings are all in hard cash, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: You must hide the whole sum immediately in the safest place you can think of.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: That I will, without sail.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Your master will be obliged to pay all costs, and charges.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: So he ought; he can afford it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: And without a penny out of your pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Just as I wou'd have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: He'll be put to the trouble of having you hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Zounds, let us try the other way first.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well then you are to be brought before Jus∣tice Mittimus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: So I am told.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Take notice of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Never fear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: To every question, ask'd you, either by the court, the plaintiff, lawyer, or myself, make no re∣ply but in the language of your own ewes, when they call their lambs; you can speak that language, can't you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Its my mother tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: The blows you have received on your head, have suggested a scheme which assisted by Mittimus's credulity may perhaps save you: but I expect to be well paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: That you shall as I am an honest man; good∣day your worship. Lord, Lord! what troubles we poor folks have to keep our own in this world. Your servant your worship; I shall remember. Baa, baa, baa. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: So, if the contrivance I have thought of to elude my neighbour's demand, does not succeed; the money I get from this new client may stop his mouth perhaps. [Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: THIS is a very busy day with me; I am to receive different sums of money from my worthy neigh∣bour lawyer Scout, and to eat a goose with him, dress'd after a receipt of the late worshipful Alderman Dum∣pling. Well, I always said the aldermen were a use∣ful body of men. But suppose I call in to see▪ how matters stand, by way of asking how he does; here's a savoury smell▪ Egad they have put down the goose already. I'll go and have a sop in the pan. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Quick, quick old Snarl is coming up; I hear him on the stairs. Now mind your cue wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: Never fear me; I'll be a good nurse I war∣rant me.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: (in a chair as sick.) Wi-f-e here's the apo∣the-cary.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: The apothecary!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: He brings me the cooling mixture.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: The cooling mixture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: O dear Sir, I hope you have brought some∣thing to give my poor husband a little ease. He has been in the condition you see this fortnight past.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: This fortnight woman, why—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: Yes, this day fortnight, of all the good days in the year, he was taken with a lunacy fit, and has not been out of the room since.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Zounds not out of the room; why he came to my house this morning by the same token he bought four yards of iron grey cloth of me, and I am come for the money. Good morrow Mr Scout.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Good morrow, good Mr Drench.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Mr Drench!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: He takes you for the apothecary Sir, pray leave the room for heaven's sake, if you can give him no relief.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: But patience; you remember Mr Scout, this morning—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Yes, this morning, I bid my wife lay by for you—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Aye, I knew he wou'd remember it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I bid her lay by for you carefully, a large glass full of my—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: A glass full! I am come for my money. Zounds is that the coin I am to be paid in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: Dear Sir, retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: When I am paid, and not before.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I beseech you let me have no more of these odious pills; they had like to have made me give up the ghost.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I wish they had made you give up my cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: (rising) Wife, see, see, three large buzzing butterflies with amber heads, and christal wings—there they go—there—tally o! hoics, hoics, tal∣ly o! ho, ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I see none of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: But you see he raves.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: (falling back in chair) Save me good folks from the doctor, and a fig for the disease.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: O he talks good sense now—Now I'll speak to him—Neighbour Scout.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: (jumping up) My client, my lord, Sir Hugh Witherington!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Sir Hugh Witherington!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Charges the defendant Sir Hugh Montgome∣ry—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Gomery! why is it possible I cou'd have mistaken another for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: Nay now you have tormented the poor man sufficiently, let him have a little rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Stay, he looks as if he wou'd speak to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: O dear Mr Snarl.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: He knows me; I said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I beg ten thousand pardons.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No apologies—well.—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: That since my arrival in this village, I haven't been to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Not been to see me! why this very day you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Yes, to day, to make my excuses, I sent an attorney of my acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: An attorney! Eh, shall I never see my cloth again? but its all a sham, you yourself was the very person, by the same token your father ow'd mine 50 pounds: Aye, aye, you may shake your head, but I sha'n't quit the place, without either my cloth or my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: This wont do I find, I must try another me∣thod. (aside) Wife, wife, don't you hear them? the thieves are breaking in at the door—but I'll bite 'em—this way—here they come—my musket—I'll shoot 'em. Stop thief! stop thief—(collars Snarl)—my mus∣ket, my musket! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: A thief! my musket, ecod, it may be danger∣ous, to argue with a madman, and a blunderbuss.

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter SCOUT, with a birch broom, which he levels at Snarl, who supposing it a musket▪ scrambles off cry∣ing out.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! he's gone at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs S.
SP.P: Yes, yes, he's gone. You have no further occasion for me; but stay you here for fear of his re∣turn. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: So, I have got a reprieve for some time at least; here he comes again: Stop thief—stop thief—stop thief—O its my new client.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: At your worship's service, Justice Mittimus is ready, and the court will sit immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Wait till I put on my gown, and be sure you remember the instructions I gave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Never fear, your worship: Baa; practice makes perfect they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: This way; we have no time to lose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: I have been improving myself this half hour past, in our pens, and now I am so fluent in talking like a sheep, that I question if his worship, and the whole bench together could beat me at it. [Exeunt.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE—The Court at the Justice's—Table, 5 chairs, Clerk, &c. discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Well, the court is assembled; and the parties may appear. Where is your lawyer, neighbour Snarl?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I am my own lawyer.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: (aside to Sheepface) How! rascal, you have impos'd upon me. Is that the plaintiff?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, that's his worship, my good master.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: (aside) How shall I get out of this scrape?—If I go off, it will rouze his suspicions; I'll e'en stay▪and outface him.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: (seeing Scout) Heyday, who have we here? the very fellow as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Neighbour Snarl, you and the Plaintiff begin—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Then you must know that this thief—

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Come, come, no▪abuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: The short and the long of it then is, that this scoundrel shepherd of mine that was, has robb'd me of fourteen wethers.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: That remains to be prov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: (aside) His voice by Jupiter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: What proof have you?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Proof—why I—I sold them this morning,—no I don't mean that—I gave him in charge four yards—no I don't mean that—fourscore sheep, I should say, and there are but threescore and six forthcoming.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I deny the fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Snail.
SP.P: Well if I had not left the other in a lunacy fit, I shou'd swear this was the very man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: This is the very man, without doubt—but that is not the point at present—the fact neighbour Snarl—prove the fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I prove it by my oath—I mean by the ac∣count of my flock;—what's become of the four yards—fourteen sheep, I should say, that are missing?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: They are dead of the rot.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Zounds! 'tis he himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Again, why I tell you once more, neighbour, nobody doubts that. It is asserted that your sheep died of the rot. What do you answer to that?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I answer that it is a confounded lie, and the proof on't is hiding myself behind the hedge, who shou'd come up but this fellow, and laying hold of one of the fattest of my wethers.—Sits down beside me, and after cajoling me for a while about Wither∣ington, Gomery, he makes no more ado, but carries off▪four yards of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Four yards of your wethers!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Eh, no—my cloth—I say my cloth—the other—

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: What other, neighbour—what other?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Dear Sir, he's mad—raving mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: I fear so—harkye, neighbour Snarl, not all the Justices in the county, no nor their clerks either, cou'd make any thing of your evidence. You talk of four∣teen wethers stole from you, and you jumble up with that four yards of cloth, and Whittington, and I don't know what.—Stick to your wethers I say, or I must discharge the prisoner, but the shortest way is to exa∣mine him myself.—Come here my good fellow—hold up your head; what is your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: He lies; his name is Sheepface.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Well Sheepface, or Baa, no matter for the name; tell me, is it true that Mr Snarl gave you four∣score sheep in charge?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: How! oh, his fears get the better of him per∣haps, come, come, don't be alarm'd—did Mr Snarl catch you at night killing one of his wethers?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Heyday, what can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why, sir, the blows the plaintiff gave the poor fellow on his head, have affected his brain, and put him, as your worship sees, beside himself. He's to be trepan'd as soon as the court breaks up, and Mr Minch∣meat the surgeon says, it is the whole Materia Medica, to a dose of jalap, that he never recovers.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Oh for the matter of that, it was dark night, and when ever I strike, I always strike home, and when and where I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: There Sir, he confesses the fact, a voluntary confession.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Aye, aye, a voluntary confession; release the prisoner, I find no cause of complaint against him.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: But I appeal—As to you Mr Irongre, we shall meet. (to Scout.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: O fie Mr Snarl, you are much to blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: To blame quotha; one runs off with my cloth; the other cuts the throats of my wethers: one pays me with Gomery, and the other with Baa; yet after all I am to blame. As for you Mr Justice—I'll appeal to a higher court; and that you shall find▪ Mr Wiseacre. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: (to Sheepface) Go thank his worship, go.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa, baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Enough, enough! poor fellow, go and be tre∣pan'd directly; go. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well I have brought you off with flying co∣lours, you see; you are a man of your word I know; and I am sure you will pay me generously as you have promis'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Yes, yes; you play'd your part very well, but that isn't the point now—my fe;—do you see—my fee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: What, am I to be outwitted by a walking scrubbing post? a two legg'd bellwether? a—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: So I am outdone here I find—but come, will you assist in bringing about my daughter's marriage. If the scheme succeeds, if you and your wife, my maid Kate, play your parts well, I shall think myself sufficiently paid—if not, I'll shew you what it is to at∣tempt cheating a lawyer.—But to your hiding place scoundrel, do you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa, baa. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P:
The devil baa you: but come, his worship seems so persuaded of the fellow's dangerous situation, that it will be no hard matter to persuade him he's at the point of death: but here he comes, and Kate along
with him. The work's begun I see; I must stay and lend a hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Poor fellow! dead do you say, and so sudden∣ly too?

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Yes—ye—es, Sir.—Oh, oh! o dear. (crying)

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Poor wench!—An ugly affair this for Mr Snarl.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: don't weep so child; I'll see justice done you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Oh! my husband! my poor dear husband! Oh, oh, oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Nay, be comforted; consider you were married only yesterday morning, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Aye, that's the reason; had he liv'd a day or two longer it wou'd have been some conso-la-ti-on, oh, oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: The murderer shall be punished; I have given the necessary orders already, and you shall shortly have the comfort of seeing him hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Hang'd! poor neighbour Snarl! so valuable a member of the community too. He'll be a public loss neighbour Mittimus; a public loss!

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: True he was a useful man in the country, but what can I do; here's a man murder'd; and his wi∣dow demands justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: But what service wou'd it be to you Kate to have Mr Snarl hang'd—wou'd it not be better to—

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Why Sir, I am not revengeful, and if there was any friendly way of making up matters, you know how I love your worship's god-daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: My god▪daughter! what concern has she in this affair?

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Why an' please your worship, Charles, Mr Snarl's only son is in love with Miss Harriet; your worship's god-daughter; but Mr Snarl won't consent to the marriage. Now your worship is a man of learn∣ing▪ and if you set about it, I am sure might contrive something to please all parties.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: I have it. We'll hush matters up on condition that Mr Snarl consents to the match, but neighbour Scout, do you consent?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why I had no intention of marrying my daughter yet; but to save Mr Snarl from being hang'd, come I consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: They are bringing him this way, I see, leave▪ us together.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I'll but just fill up the blanks of a bond, which you'll oblige him to sign; otherwise he might retract you know. [Exit Scout and Kate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Well neighbour Snarl, the poor wretch you beat, they say is dead, and you confess'd the fact you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I did; a blister on my tongue for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: The law must take its course; but first let me know whether you wou'd rather be hang'd, or con∣sent to your Son's wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Neither one, nor t'other.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Lawyer Scout has a daughter, beautiful, and well accomplish'd, and your Son is in love with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: What's that to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Now matters might be hush'd up, if you con∣sent to their marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I'll be hang'd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Away with him to prison then.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Hold! hold! I'll consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Here's a bond ready for figning, and Mr Snarl if any of my family, can be of service to you, in your present misfortune, you may command me.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Eh, what do you want another four yards of cloth rascal?—but come give me this bond. There, ▪signs it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Come, Charles, you and I will be witnesses.—So you have had a fortunate escape neighbour Snarl, I wish you joy of your good luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Yes, this has been a lucky day for me truly.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter two COUNTRYMEN dragging in SHEEPFACE.

SP.SPEAKER: Coun.
SP.P: Bring him along.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Mercy good folks!

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: Whence comes this ghost?

SP.SPEAKER: Coun.
SP.P:
Why a'nt please your worship, we found this fellow hid under a heap of barley in our barn, so we
brought him before your worship to make him give an account of himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mit.
SP.P: What's become of the blows, your master▪gave you on the head?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Gone along with his fourteen wethers.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: What rascal, you are not dead then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Let me come at him; I have paid for the kil∣ling, and it is but fair, I shou'd have the worth of my money, so if I am not allow'd to choak him I retract the consent I gave.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: With all my heart; so you may pay the pe∣nalty of your bond, which is two thousand guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Two thousand devils!—But come, no joking apart, you'll pay me the fifty pounds your father ow'd mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Yes, when you can produce me his note.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Mercy upon me! but then my four yards of cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I'll wear them at your Son's wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Well, at any rate, give me my share of the goose.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: It flew back this morning to Norfolk.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Then this rascal shall pay for all, and I'll be∣gin by having him hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Char.
SP.P:
'Tis time I own the truth Father, he has done nothing, but by my ection, and to supply my necessi∣ties, therefore suffer me to meet your future indul∣gence,
by the means of conquering all such tempta∣tions henceforward.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Hem!—well, it must be so then, I think; and to prevent any future abuse, I'll sell off all my sheep, and then they'll neither die of the rot, nor shall I need a shepherd.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well so far I have succeeded fully▪ both for myself and client; but a cause in which we are all in∣terested remains yet to be determin'd; which we must learn from the decision of this tribunal. Whether the Village Lawyer is to be struck off the roll, or not.
